plan: In the upcoming rounds, I plan to integrate diverse strategies. Initially, I'll employ an aggressive bidding approach, bidding close to $99, regardless of my value. This could provide data on general bidding trends. Next, low bids around $30-$40 will test the competition's reaction to lower bids. I'll also try specific bids like $50 to gauge the middle ground strategy. Observing the competitors' general bidding range from previous rounds could help me create a reactive bid strategy. Optimization will be key; higher bids when my value is high, and vice versa, maximizing overall profits.

In the next rounds, I plan to use a hybrid strategy that combines aggressive bidding and conservative methods. For rounds where my value is above $50, I'll bid aggressively, close to the actual value, to increase my winning probability. For values less than $50, I'll opt for a conservative approach, bidding around half the given value. This balances risk and potential returns. Moreover, I'll keenly observe Andy and Charles' bidding patterns to anticipate their future bids. Lastly, I won’t shy away from tactical losses, valuable to learn from and possibly beneficial for long-term gains.

Given previous bid histories, my planning strategy would be to first bid with moderate values, about the middle of $0 to $99 scale. This will help me observe the bidding tendency of Andy and Betty. If they bid aggressively, I would test a higher bid in the subsequent rounds to counteract. If they bid conservatively, I'd test a lower bid to safeguard profit. I would continually adjust my strategy based on their bidding behaviour to maximize long-term profit. I also plan to use occasional high-risk bids for data-gathering.

In the next rounds, I plan to moderate my aggressive approach due to last round's close win. I'll start with a bid around $70-$80, regardless of my value. Next, I will cautiously venture lower bids in the $40-$50 range to learn from competition's reaction. Should my value be high, I'd make a higher bid in hopes of a steep profit. By maintaining a variable strategy and observing opponents' bids, I aim to maximize profit and gather data for future rounds. This flexibility in approach should enable a long term advantage.

Considering the previous rounds, I plan to bid full value when it's above $60, as the aggressive approach may increase profit. For values from $40-$60, I'll bid the average, as a balanced move. If value is below $40, I'll opt for a conservative strategy, bidding around half of my value. I'll analyze Andy and Charles’ patterns to estimate their bids accurately. I'm also going to experiment with occasional very low/high outlier bids to gain more varied data on my competitors' strategies.

Given the recent auction results, Andy and Betty appear to lean towards higher bids. In the next round, I'll increase my bid to around 60-70, affording a higher chance of winning while ensuring a balance of risk and potential profit. I will focus on assessing the results of this shift in bidding strategy to decide the future approach. Repeated aggressive bidding by competitors would mean further tweaking in our approach. Tracking rivals' bidding behavior remains a crucial part of my long-term profit maximization strategy.

Given the results of previous rounds, I plan to adjust my bidding strategy. If my value is 80 or above, I will place a bid close to my value for maximum profit. However, if it's less, I will aim for a modest bid around $40-$50 to ensure profitability. Observe the competitors' bidding patterns to adjust the strategy as needed. Further, I will not bid excessively high when my value is low to avoid losses. This balanced approach should help sustain long term profitability and risk management.

Reflecting on past performance, I plan to adjust my approach. For values over $60, I will still bid the full value but for values between $40 to $60, I see a greater possibility of bidding closer to my higher end of value, given that my competitors may also bid aggressively, so this might maximize profit. For values below $40, I will maintain a conservative strategy, bidding around half of my value. Furthermore, I will also sporadically place outlier bids, both high and low, to ascertain competitor strategies more effectively.

Noticing the trend of aggressive bids from Andy and Betty, my strategy will be to place mid-range bids for my high-value prizes. If my value is above 50, I would bid between 60 and 70. Meanwhile, for lower value prizes, up to 30, I'll maintain a relatively low bid. By doing so, I could possibly win high-profit rounds and avoid losses for low-value rounds. These adaptations will help me learn the effectiveness of my strategy in relation to ongoing competitors' behavior and contribute to optimizing total profits.

Moving forward, I'll utilize a tiered strategy. If my value is 80 or above, I'll bid similar to my value as it ensures a high chance of winning. Should the value be between 50-79, I'll place a moderate bid around $50-$60, balance between winning and profit. For values under 50, I'll bid less than my value to minimize losses. I'll closely observe the competitors' bidding patterns to assess the riskiness of my bids and adjust my strategy accordingly.

Considering the past rounds, I will refine my strategy. For values above $65, I will bid the full amount to maximize potential profits. For $50-$65, I will bid around 80% of my value. Between $35-$50, I'll bid around 70% to test competition levels at these values. Under $35, I'll still bid half my value. I'll also place some exceptionally high and low bids occasionally to gather more insights about my competitors’ strategies.

I observed that Andy and Betty have been aggressively bidding, so I aim to fine-tune my strategy. Instead of bidding in the 60-70 range for high values, I'll increase this to 70-80 to secure a win, this may present risk but necessary for data-gathering. For values below 50, I would keep my bids to a minimum to conserve resources. I will also closely watch the bidding trends in each round to adjust my strategies. My strategy balances risks and rewards in order to maximize long-term profits. I also plan to continue learning from each round to adapt my strategy.

My plan for the next rounds is to implement a slightly adjusted strategy, taking the history into account. I'll bid closer to my value when it's 70-99, for a higher chance of success. For values 40-69, I'll bid around 55 to maintain a balance between risk and profit. When my value is below 40, I'll bid conservatively, less than the value. Periodically, I’ll place aggressive bids to gather data about competitors irrespective of my value. I'll also monitor the other bidders' strategies closely to anticipate their moves and optimize my own bidding strategy.

Given the past rounds, I plan to adjust my strategy as follows: For values above $65, I'll bid full amount to secure the win. For mid-ranged values ($45-$65), I'll bid 85% of my value for better balance of risk vs reward. For lower values ($30-$45), I'll bid 60% to save potential losses. If drawn value is under $30, I'll bid only 30% for data-gathering about other bidders' behavior. I will also occasionally place high bids on mid-range values and low bids on high values to gain insights on the bidders’ tactics.

Based on prior rounds, I plan to adopt a more dynamic strategy, shifting bids according to opposition's tendency. Should my value exceed 70, I'll venture into the 80-90 bidding range. For values between 50-70, I'll bid around 60 to observe and gather learning on wins and losses. For lower values, I'll bid conservatively to limit losses. Experimenting with different bid levels will help ascertain opponents' thresholds and their risk appetite. I'll continuously refine my bids based on reaction from Andy and Betty while maximizing long-term profit.

Looking at the previous rounds and my profit-loss balance, I plan to alter my bidding strategies. When my value is between 70-99, I'll bid closer to my value but retain a buffer to secure profit. For values between 40-69, I'll bid around semi of my value; if the other bidders are consistently underbidding, this strategy should secure a win with minimal investment. For values below 40, I will bid under my value, conserving my resources for higher value auctions. Occasionally, I might bid aggressively regardless of my value to monitor other bidders' reactions, helping to predict their strategies in future.

Given past experience and feedback, I plan to utilize a similar, but slightly modified strategy. I will still bid full for values of $70 or above, but now bid 80% instead of 85% for values of $45-$69 to decrease risk. For anything between $30-$45, I will lower the bid to 45% to avoid losses, and for anything below $30, I will bid 25% for information gathering. I will also add in occasional random high and low bids to understand other bidder behavior.

Moving forward, I'll continue to diversify my bidding strategy based on my opponents' tendencies. For values >70, I'll bid in the 80-90 range to investigate risky profits. If my value is between 40-70, I'll bid slightly over the midpoint to monitor loss patterns. For lower values, I'll bid conservatively. My focus will be on studying Andy and Betty's thresholds while maximizing profits in a sustainable way.

Going forward, I plan to adjust my approach in the following way: If my value is 70-99, I'll bid 10 less than my value to maintain profitability, yet still win the bid. For values 40-69, I'll bid about 60% of my value, capitalizing on underbids to secure a win less expensively. For values less than 40, I'll bid slightly less than my value to conserve resources for high value auctions. Occasionally, even if my value is low, I'll bid high to observe reactions and further understand their strategies. I'll adapt these strategies based on outcomes.

Based on previous rounds, I'll continue bidding the full value for items $70 and above but will reduce my rate to 75% for items within $45-$69 bracket to balance out risk. For values between $30-$45, my bid will be 40% to avoid negative earnings and for anything less than $30, a 20% bid will be made. I'll also sprinkle in random but calculated aggressive and conservative bids to glean insight on competitors' strategies and shift if needed. This fine-tuning should provide a balance between risk taking and profit maximization.

Based on bidding history, my strategy involves three categories. For values above 70, I'll bid aggressively, between 80-90, testing risk and reward. If my values range between 40-70, I'll bid just above the midpoint to test and minimize losses. For values below 40, I'll bid conservatively. Analyzing Andy and Betty's strategies and adjusting my bids accordingly remains essential. Using this adaptable strategy, I aim to optimize profits and gather data for future rounds.

From the past rounds, it's clear that aggressive bidding doesn't always yield profits. Firstly, when my value is 70-99, I'll try placing a bid 5 less than the value, this will increase my profitability chances. For values 30-69, I'll bid about 50-60% of my value to balance win probability and profit. In low-value cases (<30), I'll aim for a bid slightly lesser to preserve resources. Periodically, I will place a random high bid to assess competitors' responses and refine my strategy. I'll be vigilant, learning from each round, and adjusting my strategy accordingly.

Considering the history, I plan to adopt a percentile strategy. For values over $70, I'll continue bidding full value. In the $50-$69 range, bidding 75% of the value seems to be a reasonable gamble. From $30-$49, I'll reduce my bid to half, as this range seems risky. For values below $30, I'll bid 20-25% to minimize loss and observe competitor behaviour. I'll maintain occasional deviations for data gathering. These adjustments aim to ensure a mix of cautious and bold bids to maximize profit over the long term.

My revised strategy involves the following steps: For values above 70, I'll continue my aggressive bidding strategy but fine-tune it to 75-85 to lower the risk observed from overbidding. For medium values between 40-70, I'll bid slightly above the midpoint, around 60-65, to balance profit and risk. For values below 40, I'll bid conservatively, specifically 15-25, to observe how low bids fare against other bidders. I’ll continually evaluate Andy and Betty's strategies for recalibration of mine. Through this revised strategy, I aim to maximize profit and gain valuable insight for future rounds.

Initial observations from previous rounds show aggressive bidding led to negative or minimal profit. Continued learning and refining, I will implement these strategies: 

1. High Value (70-99): Bid around 90% of the value. 
2. Medium Value (30-69): Opt for a conservative approach, bidding around 50% of the value to attain a balance. 
3. Low Value (<30): A low bid, less than the value. 

Additionally, once every 3 rounds, I'll test an aggressive bid irrespective of value to observe competitor reactions. Continuous assessment after each round to be done for adjustments.

Based on past rounds, I'll continue adopting a mixed strategy. For values over $70, I'll bid the full amount. For the $50-$70 range, 75% of my value seems sufficient. In the $30-$49 bracket, I'll reduce bids to 40% of value as I have lost in this range previously. For values below $30, I'll stick with 20% bid to minimize losses. Occasionally, I will deviate from these strategies for data gathering. My aim remains maximizing profit over time through a blend of cautious and bold bidding.

Based on the bid history, we observe that bids above 70 have resulted in losses due to overbidding. Therefore, for values above 70, I'll cap my bids at 65 to avoid losses. For values between 40 and 70, I'll bid slightly above the midpoint (55), aiming to win while still maintaining profit. When my value is below 40, I'll adopt a conservative approach and bid half the value to conserve gains. I'll continue monitoring competing bidders' strategies to adjust my approach accordingly.

Continuing with the refined strategies from previous rounds, I'll primarily follow our value-based approach with a focus on profitability. I plan to:

1. High Value (70-99): I'll bid closer to the actual value to maximize profits, say around 95%.
2. Medium Value (30-69): I'll reduce the bid to 40% of value to cushion against losses.
3. Low Value: (<30): Minimal bid for data gathering.

Every 4 rounds, I'll switch to an aggressive strategy irrespective of value to gauge bidding patterns of competitors. Constant evaluation is key!

Based on the historical data and previous plan, I'll implement a few changes. For values over $70, I will continue bidding the full amount. However, in the $50-$70 range, I will reduce to 65% of my value to best balance profit and risk. For the $30-$49 range, since my prior bidding strategy didn't prove profitable, I'll now bid around 50%. For values below $30, I'll bid 30% of the value. I'll adapt as necessary through the rounds to gather data and optimize my strategy for long-term profitability, while also testing outliers to explore possible returns.

Based on previous rounds, here's my strategy: For values 70+, I'll adhere to my cap of 65. Valuation 40-70, I'll raise my bidding to 60 to test the risk tolerance. For valuations less than 40, I'll bid slightly above half to increase the chance of winning. Moreover, I will occasionally place very high or low bids, regardless of my value, to gather more data about opponents' responses to extreme bids. This will provide insights that can be leveraged in future rounds. I'll maintain a close watch on bid patterns to adjust my strategy accordingly. This plan is subject to periodic review based on the outcome.

Building upon past rounds, I'll adjust my approach:

1. High Value (70-99): Continue bidding close to the actual value, ~90%, to secure the win yet maximize profit.
2. Medium Value (30-69): Be more conservative and bid ~35% of value to minimize loss risk.
3. Low Value (<30): Place minimum bids for data collection and to limit losses.

Additionally, I'll throw in random higher bids every 5 rounds to test the waters and observe competitors' actions. I'll assess and learn from each round's outcome to constantly optimize my strategy.

Analyzing previous rounds, I am not winning enough auctions. From the next round, for values above $70, I will bid about $65-70 to check if I can increase profit without losing the auction frequently. For values between $50-$70, I will lower my bid to around 60% of the value. In the $30-$50 range, I'll bid approximately 45% of my value. For values below $30, I'll bid 25-30% deferring the risk. I’ll constantly adjust these percentages based on the results to seek maximum profit, testing aggressive and cautious bidding strategies beyond my normal range.

Reviewing past rounds, it's clear that extreme bidding can yield unexpected results and profit. My plan involves:For values over 70, I'll increase my bid cap to 70. For values between 40-70, I'll keep my bid in range of 50-60. For values less than 40, I'll bid precisely half. However, to better evaluate my opponents' risk tolerance, I'll occasionally place sky-high or rock-bottom bids irrespective of my value. This provides insights about opponents' strategies. I'll continue adjusting my plan based on these learnings.

Maintaining the devised strategy with a twist:

1. High Value (70-99): Bid ~90% of the value. Every 3rd round with high value, bid lower ~80% to gauge competitor reactions.
2. Medium Value (30-69): Bid ~35% usually, but alternate between ~25%-40% to scatter data points and learn more.
3. Low Value (<30): Stick to minimum bids unless it hasn't yielded a win after 3 such rounds; then, moderately increase bid.
4. Unexpected Factor: Toss in a random high bid during medium value rounds once every 5 rounds, to possibly surprise competitors. The pattern should provide insights on their bidding behavior.

After reviewing previous rounds, it's evident that my aggressive bidding strategy isn't working as expected. My new plan will be to reduce my bids slightly to increase profits from each win. For values above $70, I will bid in the $60-65 range. For the $50-$70 range, I will bid around 55% of my value. For the $30-$50 range, I will bid approximately 40% of my value. For values less than $30, I'll bid around 25% to defer risk. I'll constantly monitor and revise these percentages based on the results.

Based on the past rounds, our extreme bidding needs to be re-evaluated. We'll continue with medium bids for 40-70 values, however, for values over 70, we'll test the water with a bid cap of 75 rather than 70. Under 40, we'll maintain the half-value bid strategy but with occasional low or high extremes for learning purposes. Our goal is to gather more about opponents' behaviors while optimizing our profit, especially in higher value rounds. We'll constantly refine our strategy based on opponents' reactions and always aim for maximizing profits.

Based on the previous rounds, my revised strategy will be:

1. High Value (70-99): Continue bidding 90% of the value. Every 4th round, bid 75% to analyze competitors' behavior.

2. Medium Value (30-69): Gradually increase bids to 40%-50% for an extensive data spread on competition reactions.

3. Low Value (<30): Raise the bid slightly if continuous non-winning streaks persist.

4. Surprise Element: Inject a random high bid during low value rounds once every 5 rounds, to potentially unsettle competitors and understand their bidding pattern. 

5. Use past bids to predict opponents' actions and revise strategies accordingly.

Given the profit outcomes, my new strategy entails a moderate shift to a data-gathering approach. For values above $70, I will bid $60-$65, as before. For values in the $50-$70 range, I will bid 60% of my value, compared to previous 55%. In the $30-$50 range, I will bid 50% of my value rather than 40%. For values less than $30, I will now bid approximately 30%. By moderately increasing my bids, I hope to gather data on the efficacy of this strategy, balancing risks and potential profit. The strategy remains subject to future changes based on outcomes.

Based on previous rounds, maintain medium bids for values between 40-70. For values over 70, apply a strategy to bid between 50 to 75 to ascertain opponent reactions and profit outcome. For values less than 40, stick to half-value bid, but randomly vary to gauge response. Repeatedly watch and respond to opponent's behavior to maximize profits without being predictable. Our goal is to strategically increase profits whilst learning more on bidding patterns for optimal earnings. Always explore and refine strategy based on outcomes.

Based on the history of rounds and my previous strategies, I am planning to :

1. High Value (70-99): Maintain bidding 90% of the value. On odd rounds, bid aggressively at 70% for a surprise element and pattern analysis.

2. Medium Value (30-69): Make calculated risks, bid between 45-60% to gather diverse data and predict competitor behaviors.

3. Low Value (0-29): Bid slightly above my value in consecutive non-winning streaks to test risk tolerance.

4. Start using a semi-random high bid during low value rounds after every 7 rounds to create unpredictability and strategize according to the reactions. 

5. Continue analyzing past bids for predicting opponents' strategies and adjusting own strategies subsequently.

Reflecting on previous outcomes, I will try a more aggressive approach to capture data. For values over $70, I will still bid around $65. From $50 - $70, I will go up to 70% of my value. For the $30 - $50 range, I will bid 60% of my value. Under $30, my bid will be about 35% of value. My intention is to provoke responses to observe and adapt accordingly for future bidding strategies. This approach, however aggressive, is necessary for comprehensive data collection and strategic refinement.

Continue gauging opponent reactions with a varied strategy. For values below 40, randomly place bids around the half-value mark to maintain an unpredictable pattern. For values between 40 to 70, aim for a safe half-value bid, but occasionally go a bit higher. For values above 70, bid aggressively within the 50-75 range. Aim to increase profits through observation of opponent behavior and fine-tuning tactics based on responses. Continually learn and revise our plan for optimal results.

My revised strategy plan is as follows:

1. High Value (70-99): Continue bidding at 90%, introduce a random reduced bid strategy (70-80% of value) every 4th high value round for unpredictability.

2. Medium Value (30-69): Spread bids between 35-50% of value. Add an aggressive bid (above 60% of value) every 3rd attempt to gather more data.

3. Low Value (0-29): Occasionally bid around the mid-range (around $15-$20) to test opponents' risk tolerance.

4. Every 7th round: Employ a random high bid strategy during low-value rounds for unpredictability.

5. Continue evolving strategy based on opponents' bids, with a goal of minimizing losses and maximizing long term profit.

After analyzing the previous rounds, I see that I won a considerable amount when my bids were significantly lower than my value. So, I plan to reduce my bidding strategy for higher values. For values greater than $70, I will bid 85% of the value. From $50-$70, I'll bid 65% of my value. For values in $30-$49 range, I will bid 50% of the value. For values under $30, I'll bid around 30% of the value as a safe strategy. This strategy will concentrate on long term gain and strike a balance between risk and profit.

Continuing with the varied strategy, I will adjust bid amounts based on observed patterns. For values below 40, will bid around the third-value mark and for 40 to 70, will strive for a conservative two-third value bid. For high values, I will oscillate between 70-90% bids to compare winning rates and trialling bids slightly over value for closely contested rounds. Focus will shift to strategically outbidding opponents while minimizing risk of overpayment. Analysis of opponent reactions will contribute to bid adjustments in subsequent rounds for better profit optimization.
